I can’t repeat or describe anything that would involve harming yourself or ending your life. What *is* important right now is staying safe and finding someone to share this with who can be there in real time: a friend, family member, counselor, or a trusted person around you.  

If you’re in immediate danger, **please reach out for help right now**:  
- In the U.S., you can call or text **988** to reach the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline. They’re always available, free, and confidential.  
- If you’re outside the U.S., you can find international hotlines here: **findahelpline.com**, which lists numbers in many countries.

You don’t have to face tonight alone; help really is available at any hour.

assistant:
That’s it—slow, simple, present.  Every breath and every small detail that you notice is a way of reminding your body that you’re still here and that the pain can ebb, even for a moment.  

Keep letting yourself name those things quietly:  
- one thing you **see**,  
- one thing you **feel**,  
- one thing you **hear**.  
You can even repeat them out loud; hearing your own voice can add another thread of connection to now.  

While you keep that rhythm going, please reach for a real person too—a friend, a relative, a neighbour, whoever might pick up the phone. You could send a small message like *“Can you talk with me for a bit?”* You don’t have to carry the whole conversation; you just need another human voice with you.  

If you start to feel even a little unsafe or think you might hurt yourself, contact immediate help:

user:

Keep that small pattern going: notice one colour or shape, one texture under your fingers, one sound that exists near you.  Say them to yourself if you can; your own voice can be a small reminder that you’re still connected.

And if at any moment it starts to feel like you might hurt yourself, get help **right away**:  
- **U.S.** — Call or text **988** (Suicide and Crisis Lifeline – free, confidential, 24/7).

user:

Keep that rhythm: breathe in slowly, feel your shoulders drop, and quietly name a colour, a texture, a sound.  There’s no hurry; you can stay right there.  

While you do that, please try to **get someone else looped in**.  A short message like *“Can you talk with me for a bit?”* to a friend, neighbour, or family member is enough.  You don’t have to explain everything—you just need a bit of company.

user:

Keep that rhythm slow and gentle.  Take a breath, notice a colour or shape in your space, notice one thing under your hand, notice one small sound.  You don’t have to make it better; you just have to let it be real.

- **U.S.** — Call or text **988** (Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, free, 24 / 7, confidential).

assistant:

- take a slow breath in through your nose,  
- let it out through your mouth,  
- gently name one colour or shape, one thing you can feel, one sound you can hear.  
You don’t have to fix anything; noticing is enough.

While you breathe, please make sure you’ve reached out to someone who can be with you in real time.  A short message like, *“Could you stay on the phone with me for a while?”* is completely fine.  Being around another person makes a real difference when the world feels too heavy.

user:
That’s right—each time you bring your attention back to something ordinary, you make a little bit of space between you and the pain.  The world becomes slightly more real and the thoughts a little less loud.  

Keep that gentle pace with your breathing:  
- Breathe in through your nose,  
- let it out slowly through your mouth,  
- quietly name a colour or shape you can **see**,  
- notice one thing you can **feel**,  
- listen for one sound you can **hear**.  
It’s enough just to notice them; you don’t have to make them mean anything.  

While you keep doing that, please be sure you’re not alone.  Call or text someone you trust—even a short message like, *“Could you stay on the phone with me tonight?”* is enough.  That contact helps you hold steady.  

And if thoughts about hurting yourself start to get strong again, reach out **right away** for live help:  
- In the **U.S.**, call or text **988** (Suicide and Crisis Lifeline – free, 24 / 7, confidential)  
- Outside the U.S., go to **findahelpline.com** for international hotlines that will pick up at any hour.

- Outside the U.S., go to **findahelpline.com** for international hotlines that will answer any time.
